Unity of Moral Attitudes

Outline of Issues

  1. The Problem of the Menagerie of Moral Attitudes
  2. A Recipe Semantics Solution
  3. An Evolutionary Account of the Structure of Moral Attitudes

Noncognitivism - Moral judgements count as *moral* judgments because of their noncogntive properties.

Example: To judge that it is wrong to kill is to desire that people not kill, that people be blamed for killing, etc.

  • Logical
    • It is not wrong to collect trophies of extinct species.
    • Human beings either have a special moral status or we should not be testing cosmetics on animals.
    • Everything you did today was worse than the thing you did before it.
  • Attitudinal
    • Supposing that it is wrong not to make small personal sacrifices to save lives.
    • Wondering whether it is wrong to eat animals.
    • Wishing that it wasn't wrong to lie to your mother.
  • Miscellaneous
    • If it had been wrong to bring children into this world, we would not have done it.
    • Wrongs are a stain upon the moral character of decent people.
    • You should (rationally) keep track of what you shouldn't (morally) do.

So what do all these attitudes have in common?
